de.fhb.sailboat.communication.clientModules

Class MissionTransmitter

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.fhb.sailboat.communication.MissionNegotiationBase
      • de.fhb.sailboat.communication.clientModules.MissionTransmitter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    TransmissionModule, Planner

    public class MissionTransmitter
extends MissionNegotiationBase
implements TransmissionModule, Planner
    Transmitter module for serializing and sending a mission with all its Tasks over the underlying OutputStream.
    The module ensures a reliable transmission of the mission to the connected endpoint, using three-way-handshake and mission transmission modes.
    Author:
    Michael Kant

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Description copied from interface: Planner
        Stops executing the current mission. To avoid the boat being pushed around without control, it will try to hold its current position.
        Specified by:

      • receivedObject

        public void receivedObject(java.io.DataInputStream stream)
                    throws java.io.IOException
        Description copied from interface: TransmissionModule
        Called on a registered TransmissionModule, if the related CommunicationBase received a transmission
        that's intended for this TransmissionModule.
        The given TransmissionModule is supposed to decode the data on its own.
        Specified by:

        Parameters:
        stream - Stream that provides the data.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - IOException that's back-propagated to the underlying CommunicationBase, if this TransmissionModule doesn't handle the exception itself.

      • skipNextCycle

        public boolean skipNextCycle()
        Description copied from interface: TransmissionModule
        This can be used to get the underlying ModuleWorker to skip the next pending transmission request.
        A useful method for bandwidth optimization.
        Specified by:
        skipNextCycle in interface TransmissionModule
        Returns:
        True if the next cycle shall be skipped, otherwise false.

      • requestObject

        public void requestObject(java.io.DataOutputStream stream)
                   throws java.io.IOException
        Description copied from interface: TransmissionModule
        Called by the underlying ModuleWorker, if the TransmissionModule's transmission interval has been reached and a new object or bunch of data is supposed to be sent.
        The given TransmissionModule is supposed to encode the data on its own.
        Mind, this method is just called if the given transmission interval is greater than 0. (see TransmissionModule.getTransmissionInterval())
        Specified by:
        requestObject in interface TransmissionModule
        Parameters:
        stream - Stream that takes the data.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - IOException that's back-propagated to the underlying ModuleWorker, if this TransmissionModule doesn't handle the exception itself.

      • connectionReset

        Specified by:
        connectionReset in interface TransmissionModule

      • getTransmissionInterval

        public int getTransmissionInterval()
        Description copied from interface: TransmissionModule
        Defines the transmission interval of this TransmissionModule.
        The return value is interpreted as milliseconds.
        Setting a transmission interval of 0 or less will cause the TransmissionModule to be declared as passive.
        That means it can just receive incoming objects by TransmissionModule.receivedObject(DataInputStream) because TransmissionModule.requestObject(DataOutputStream) is never being called automatically.
        However, TransmissionModule.requestObject(DataOutputStream) can still be called by explicit request over the communication base.
        Specified by:
        getTransmissionInterval in interface TransmissionModule
        Returns:
        The transmission interval value.

      • getPriority

        public int getPriority()
        Description copied from interface: TransmissionModule
        Defines the priority of this TransmissionModule. The higher the priority, the bigger the chance of outgoing data to be preferred on low bandwidth.
        The estimated priority is descending with an ascending priority value. e.g. The highest priority is 1.
        A priority value of 0 or less is however interpreted as no priority at all, which causes given packets to be added to the very end of the priority chain.
        Note: This method is NOT taken into account in the current version of the communication component yet!
        Specified by:
        getPriority in interface TransmissionModule
        Returns:
        The priority value of the TransmissionModule
